snippet: European finance ministers promised up to $125 billion in aid, which they hope will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of elections in Greece next week that could roil world markets.
abstract: Spain, responding to urgent calls from across Europe and the United States, agrees to accept a bailout for its cash-starved banks as European finance ministers offer an aid package of up to $125 billion; leaders hope the promise of such a large package will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of Greek elections that could further shake world markets.

byline.original: By RAPHAEL MINDER, NICHOLAS KULISH and PAUL GEITNER
byline.contributor: Raphael Minder reported from Madrid, Nicholas Kulish from Berlin, and Paul Geitner from Brussels. Annie Lowrey contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: European finance ministers promised up to $125 billion in aid, which they hope will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of elections in Greece next week that could roil world markets.

headline.seo: Spain Accepts Bailout Deal From Europeans for Its Banks
headline.main: Spain to Accept Rescue From Europe for Its Ailing Banks
headline.print_headline: Spain to Accept European Rescue For Ailing Banks
